title: Trump Declares U.S.-Taliban Talks Dead, Makes New Threat
text:
President Trump declared that talks were dead between the U.S. and the Taliban, the insurgent movement in Afghanistan, and warned the U.S. could do “certain things” that would cost millions of lives in a move to end the war, a step he said he doesn’t want to take.

The comments, made to reporters as he departed the White House for an appearance in North Carolina on Monday, cast new doubt on the future of the 18-year U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan after more than a year of talks between the Washington and the Taliban led to what U.S. envoy Zalmay Khalilzad last week called the threshold of an agreement that appeared in jeopardy on Monday.

Mr. Trump earlier had scheduled a meeting at Camp David with leaders of the Taliban and the Afghan government to discuss the possible agreement, but said on Saturday that he called off the meetings after a U.S. soldier was killed by a Taliban car bomb last week.

After canceling the meeting at the presidential retreat in Maryland, Mr. Trump said the U.S.-Taliban talks had ended.

“They’re dead. They’re dead. As far as I’m concerned, they’re dead,” he said Monday.

Mr. Trump’s pronouncement appeared to contradict comments on Sunday by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who said in several televised interviews that he hoped negotiations continue. “I hope we get them started back,” he said on Fox News. “It will ultimately be up to the Taliban.”

Mr. Pompeo is among those who have proposed continuing talks with the Taliban, a person familiar with the administration deliberations said. Mr. Pompeo on Sunday said Mr. Khalilzad was being recalled to Washington “to chart the path forward,” indicating talks could resume.

State Department officials didn’t respond to questions on Monday about Mr. Khalilzad’s plans to return or Mr. Pompeo’s view of the talks in light of Mr. Trump’s remarks.

Mr. Trump last year called off a planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un weeks before the meeting, and threatened to take military action if necessary. He soon reversed course, and the summit was held as scheduled.

The developments left uncertain the status of possible U.S. troop withdrawals from Afghanistan. Under proposed terms of a U.S.-Taliban agreement, the U.S. would withdraw about 5,000 troops within 135 days after completion of the deal. There are currently about 14,500 U.S. troops in Afghanistan.

The U.S. military has refused to publicly discuss its force posture. U.S. officials on Monday said there are no immediate plans to decrease the number of U.S. troops in Afghanistan. One official said the Pentagon is still sorting out the status of the talks.

Mr. Trump has said before that the U.S. could take drastic military action to end the war, but has said he doesn’t want to do so. “We would beat them very easily militarily if we wanted to, by doing certain things, and I’m not talking nuclear,” he said on Monday. “We could have that over with very, very rapidly, but you would lose millions and millions of lives, and I don’t want to do that.”

In July, Mr. Trump said, “If I wanted to win that war, Afghanistan would be wiped off the face of the Earth.” He added he wouldn’t take such a step because he didn’t want to kill 10 million people.

He denied on Monday that he had overruled top aides by pursuing a set of meetings involving the Taliban at Camp David.

Mr. Trump decided to hold the meeting at the Maryland retreat even though Vice President Mike Pence and national security adviser John Bolton advised that such a summit could be problematic, people familiar with the discussions said.

Mr. Trump said in a tweet on Saturday that he had decided to cancel the previously unannounced Camp David meeting because of the death of the U.S. soldier last week. Speaking to reporters on Monday, Mr. Trump said he didn’t consult any advisers before canceling the meeting. “I took my own advice,” he said.

Mr. Bolton had tried to counter the plan for a Camp David meeting for several days and Mr. Pence told Mr. Trump he believed Mr. Bolton was correct on the issue, adding that inviting the Taliban could have serious political implications, a person familiar with the discussions said.

Mr. Trump in a Twitter post Monday afternoon didn’t dispute the existence of opposition to his plan to hold Camp David talks, but he denied that the decision to try to go ahead with the meeting caused turmoil at the White House.

“I always think it is good to meet and talk, but in this case I decided not to,” he wrote.

Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter that it is fake news to report that he “overruled the VP and various advisers on a potential Camp David meeting with the Taliban. This story is False!” he wrote.

Mr. Trump told reporters he had been open to meeting the Taliban at Camp David, saying criticism of the plan wasn’t as important as ending the war. He added that he wouldn’t meet the Taliban at the White House, saying that was a step too far.

Afghan President Ashraf Ghani speaks during a ceremony to introduce the new chief of the intelligence service in Kabul on Monday. His government was sidelined in the U.S.-Taliban talks that President Trump on Monday declared to be dead. Photo: Rahmat Gul/Associated Press

Mr. Khalilzad has negotiated with the Taliban over the past year on ways to reduce violence and wind down the U.S. involvement in Afghanistan. A tentative agreement didn’t involve the Afghan government.

Messrs. Khalilzad and Bolton have long known each other and often don’t see eye to eye on various issues, a person familiar with their relationship said, adding that tensions in their relationship dated back to the administration of George W. Bush in the early 2000s.

Plans to hold talks with the Taliban at Camp David also drew criticism from members of Congress, some noting that the retreat served as the site for planning U.S. responses to the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

Write to Vivian Salama at vivian.salama@wsj.com and Michael C. Bender at Mike.Bender@wsj.com
description: The president warned the U.S. could do “certain things” that would cost millions of lives in a move to end the war, a step he said he doesn’t want to take.
